category_summary:
A philosophical debate about AI intelligence dominated today's discourse. **Yann LeCun** [cited **Fields Medalist Hugo Duminil-Copin**](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-f170d37e7a5a) to argue math olympiad performance doesn't equal brilliance, with **NYU's Andrew Wilson** and **DeepMind's Shane Legg** reinforcing that current [evals miss creativity](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-f7915dd37b56) and [continual learning](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-d14ac20a0ec0).

- **Cursor** [launched experimental fast mode](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-301f96fe9d53) for **Claude Opus 4.6**, described as a 'huge unlock' for tricky problems with $50 free credits for Pro/Max users
- **Simon Willison** documented **Strong DM's** radical ['Software Factory'](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-24a516bb6426) where AI writes all code without human intervention‚Äîat $1,000/engineer/day in tokens
- **Yohei Nakajima** [released **BabyAGI 3**](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-4d2442052e9d) with SMS/email, self-tool creation, and graph-based memory, plus a detailed [comparison of agent architectures](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-a0367f1f6394)
- **Allie K Miller** shared a compelling [GPT-5 lab automation workflow](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-6cdc3e26f39d) where AI proposed experiments and robots executed them

**Jerry Liu** [revealed VLMs still struggle](/?date=2026-02-08&category=social#item-8a96c3f83025) with precise line chart parsing despite strong coarse understanding.
category_summary_html:
A philosophical debate about AI intelligence dominated today's discourse. Yann LeCun cited Fields Medalist Hugo Duminil-Copin to argue math olympiad performance doesn't equal brilliance, with NYU's Andrew Wilson and DeepMind's Shane Legg reinforcing that current evals miss creativity and continual learning.

  • Cursor launched experimental fast mode for Claude Opus 4.6, described as a 'huge unlock' for tricky problems with $50 free credits for Pro/Max users
  • Simon Willison documented Strong DM's radical 'Software Factory' where AI writes all code without human intervention‚Äîat $1,000/engineer/day in tokens
  • Yohei Nakajima released BabyAGI 3 with SMS/email, self-tool creation, and graph-based memory, plus a detailed comparison of agent architectures
  • Allie K Miller shared a compelling GPT-5 lab automation workflow where AI proposed experiments and robots executed them

Jerry Liu revealed VLMs still struggle with precise line chart parsing despite strong coarse understanding.

items.title: @alz_zyd_ Hugo Duminil-Copin, French mathematician and 2022 Field Medalist told me he never particip...
items.content:
@alz_zyd_ Hugo Duminil-Copin, French mathematician and 2022 Field Medalist told me he never participated in math competition and was very bad at it.
Innovative mathematics requires creativity, intuition, intense concentration, and long reflections, sometimes spread over several years.
Good performance at a math olympiad merely tests fast problem solving abilities. AI can do that nowadays.
One of the big activities of a researcher, in mathematics and elsewhere, is not to answer questions but to ask the right questions.
items.author: @ylecun
items.summary: Yann LeCun argues that math olympiad performance doesn't equal mathematical brilliance, citing Fields Medalist Hugo Duminil-Copin who was bad at competitions. Claims innovative math requires creativity and asking the right questions - not fast problem solving that AI can now do.

@alz_zyd_ Hugo Duminil-Copin, French mathematician and 2022 Field Medalist told me he never participated in math competition and was very bad at it.

Innovative mathematics requires creativity, intuition, intense concentration, and long reflections, sometimes spread over several years.

Good performance at a math olympiad merely tests fast problem solving abilities. AI can do that nowadays.

One of the big activities of a researcher, in mathematics and elsewhere, is not to answer questions but to ask the right questions.

items.title:
AI proposed the experiments. 
Scripts validated them as possible. 
Robots ran the experiments. 
Data...
items.content:
AI proposed the experiments. 
Scripts validated them as possible. 
Robots ran the experiments. 
Data (result) was fed back into GPT-5. 
Humans updated the protocols. 
New experiments were proposed. 

Six iterations and 36000+ reaction compositions later, they achieved 40% reduction in protein production cost. 

Businesses: the handoff moments and cadence and responsibilities between humans and AI is shifting - and quickly, I might add. 

(Remember also that case studies can take weeks or months to write. The model behind this successful experiment is now 6 months old and they only ran it on one protein at the time.)
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Building on [Social](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-2df073131aa1) coverage from earlier this week, Allie K Miller describes a GPT-5-powered lab automation workflow where AI proposed experiments, robots executed them, and humans updated protocols. After 36,000+ reaction compositions across 6 iterations, they achieved 40% reduction in protein production cost. Notes the rapid shift in human-AI handoff responsibilities.
items.reasoning: Highly substantive case study of AI-human-robot collaboration in scientific research. Credible author (AI expert), strong engagement (10.8K views), concrete metrics, and forward-looking insights about enterprise AI adoption patterns.

items.title:
@PalmerLuckey Dude, government investment in AI in France is actually quite large.

For example, Fra...
items.content:
@PalmerLuckey Dude, government investment in AI in France is actually quite large.

For example, France has had a national GPU clusters for academic researchers for a while: Jean Zay since 2019 (126 pflops) and Alice Recoque in 2026 (1 petaflops). There is still no such thing in the US.

These 30M‚Ç¨ are merely a small pot to attract academics from abroad (salary bump, start-up package, etc). 
That should be compared with what, say, the University of California system spends on attracting new top faculty.

https://t.co/UeEM6KdUkk

items.summary: LeCun details France's significant AI infrastructure investments: Jean Zay cluster (126 pflops since 2019), Alice Recoque (1 exaflops in 2026). Notes US has no equivalent national academic GPU cluster. The ‚Ç¨30M being discussed is just for faculty recruitment.

items.title:
Parsing line charts is a hard task for VLMs

VLMs are generally fine at coarse visual understanding,...
items.content:
Parsing line charts is a hard task for VLMs

VLMs are generally fine at coarse visual understanding, but they have a hard time reasoning about precise coordinates. Ask most VLMs, even though tuned to chart understanding, to parse a line chart to a table and they will struggle.

We tested over a few samples. Docling‚Äôs new granite-vision model, gemini 3 flash, gpt 5.2 pro, and a v0.1 of our own chart parsing (which is in beta and rapidly evolving).

Out of these, most models fail, and sometimes miss the entire chart correctly. gpt 5.2 pro is closest but spends an absurd number of tokens reasoning through each point. Our own parsing is actually quite good, though of course, there‚Äôs still some things we need to do to get to 100% accuracy.

If you want to parse complex documents with diagrams/charts, come check out LlamaCloud! https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) analyzes VLM performance on line chart parsing. Tests Docling's granite-vision, Gemini 3 Flash, GPT 5.2 Pro. Most models struggle with precise coordinate reasoning; GPT 5.2 Pro closest but token-heavy.
items.reasoning: Technical benchmarking from credible source (LlamaIndex founder). Practical insights on VLM limitations for document understanding tasks. References multiple current models.
items.summary_html: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) analyzes VLM performance on line chart parsing. Tests Docling's granite-vision, Gemini 3 Flash, GPT 5.2 Pro. Most models struggle with precise coordinate reasoning; GPT 5.2 Pro closest but token-heavy.

We tested over a few samples. Docling‚Äôs new granite-vision model, gemini 3 flash, gpt 5.2 pro, and a v0.1 of our own chart parsing (which is in beta and rapidly evolving).

Out of these, most models fail, and sometimes miss the entire chart correctly. gpt 5.2 pro is closest but spends an absurd number of tokens reasoning through each point. Our own parsing is actually quite good, though of course, there‚Äôs still some things we need to do to get to 100% accuracy.

If you want to parse complex documents with diagrams/charts, come check out LlamaCloud! https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8

Use it when you want to be locked in, like when iter...
items.content:
Fast mode is a new experiment in Claude Code. 

Use it when you want to be locked in, like when iterating on a design or fixing an incident vs multi-Clauding in the background. 

It's more expensive because it uses more compute, but it's the exact same intelligence.

items.title: As I floated in our @yitayml pod, there are 3 kinds of World Model discussions: 1) single player 3D ...
items.content:
As I floated in our @yitayml pod, there are 3 kinds of World Model discussions: 1) single player 3D video models like Genie 3, 2) latent learning prediction like JEPA.

just published our first article on the third: World models for adversarial reasoning and theory of mind, and why LLMs are still hopelessly inefficient in this kind of problem domain despite the past 3 years of progress.

I think @ankit2119 is one of the strongest guest authors we have ever featured. proud to publish this today!

Most AI can translate 100+ languages.

But it still struggles with one of the most human forms of communication.

Sign language.

Not because it‚Äôs niche, but because it‚Äôs fundamentally harder than text or speech.

@GoogleDeepMind and I break down what just changed. https://t.co/pduTuPm1r3

items.title:
I write way less code now than I ever have.

I also feel more in control of what I'm building than a...
items.content:
I write way less code now than I ever have.

I also feel more in control of what I'm building than at any point in my career.

Every line I do write carries more weight. Each unit of effort has an outsized influence on the final product.

I'm not sure whether agentic coding is a net positive overall, but so far, it seems very helpful for my work.

I'm not sure whether agentic coding is a net positive overall, but so far, it seems very helpful for my work.

items.title:
memory is what you'd expect from someone who loves graphs, but i added clustering and summaries:

- ...
items.content:
memory is what you'd expect from someone who loves graphs, but i added clustering and summaries:

- store all logs, which are tied to skills/chat session
- extract entities and relationships from logs
- entities are clustered, and summaries are periodically generated on clusters to create a summary tree of sorts
items.author: @yoheinakajima
items.summary: BabyAGI 3 memory architecture uses graphs with clustering and summaries: stores all logs, extracts entities/relationships, clusters entities, and generates periodic cluster summaries creating a summary tree.
items.reasoning: Technical details on novel memory approach for agents from BabyAGI creator. Valuable for agent developers.
items.summary_html: BabyAGI 3 memory architecture uses graphs with clustering and summaries: stores all logs, extracts entities/relationships, clusters entities, and generates periodic cluster summaries creating a summary tree.
items.content_html:
memory is what you'd expect from someone who loves graphs, but i added clustering and summaries:

  • store all logs, which are tied to skills/chat session
  • extract entities and relationships from logs
  • entities are clustered, and summaries are periodically generated on clusters to create a summary tree of sorts

items.title:
one big difference is my opinionated approach to tools:

- it comes w a few core tools
- it has opti...
items.content:
one big difference is my opinionated approach to tools:

- it comes w a few core tools
- it has optional tools (that i want like @browseruse)
- it can use @composio actions
- skills it creates are stored in a db
- it can read skill md files and store it
- all skills are part of the same class
- dynamic loading of non-core skills
- runs in @e2b
items.author: @yoheinakajima
items.summary: BabyAGI 3's opinionated tool architecture: core tools, optional tools (browseruse), Composio actions, skills stored in DB, skill markdown files, dynamic loading of non-core skills, runs in e2b.
items.reasoning: Detailed technical breakdown of tool management in BabyAGI 3, integrating multiple frameworks (browseruse, composio, e2b).
items.summary_html: BabyAGI 3's opinionated tool architecture: core tools, optional tools (browseruse), Composio actions, skills stored in DB, skill markdown files, dynamic loading of non-core skills, runs in e2b.
items.content_html:
one big difference is my opinionated approach to tools:

  • it comes w a few core tools
  • it has optional tools (that i want like @browseruse)
  • it can use @composio actions
  • skills it creates are stored in a db
  • it can read skill md files and store it
  • all skills are part of the same class
  • dynamic loading of non-core skills
  • runs in @e2b

‚Äî
Author‚Äô...
items.content:
Mathematics of Machine Learning: https://t.co/07exFk5LqL by @TivadarDanka v/ @PacktDataML 
‚Äî
Author‚Äôs GitHub: https://t.co/01TtZt15RH
‚Äî
My review:

ùóßùóµùó≤ ùó¶ùó≤ùòÅ ùó¢ùó≥ ùó†ùóÆùòÅùóµùó≤ùó∫ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùóπ ùóîùóπùó¥ùóºùóøùó∂ùòÅùóµùó∫ùòÄ ùóßùóµùóÆùòÅ ùóüùó≤ùóÆùóøùóª ùóôùóøùóºùó∫ ùóòùòÖùóΩùó≤ùóøùó∂ùó≤ùóªùó∞ùó≤

This massive book is incredible, with its comprehensive coverage of numerous fields of mathematics and their intersection with the world of AI, data science, and machine learning (AI+DSML). I remember the very first time that I encountered machine learning. This was 20+ years ago, and that was already after 20+ years of being drenched in advanced mathematics as an astrophysicist. 

That first encounter of mine with ML was this definition: "Machine learning is the set of mathematical algorithms that learn from experience" (slightly paraphrased from the original quote by Tom Mitchell, CMU). That definition surprised me, confused me, motivated me, and changed the course of my career from astrophysics into AI+DSML. 

This book by Tivadar Danka captures the full meaning of that definition. The book covers thoroughly the many areas and domains of mathematics through which patterns in data are detected, described, learned, and recognized - all for the benefit of powering ML and AI algorithms, applications, and aspirations. 

This book will motivate you, surprise you, and inspire you in many ways, no matter what level of mathematics has (or has not) already propelled your career journey. There is room for all of us to grow. 

This is a great book, worthy to sit on everyone's desktop, ready to help you explore and exploit the full set of mathematical algorithms that learn from experience. 

The book is accompanied by a rich GitHub code repository of Jupyter notebooks. Learn by doing! Do by learning!

Disclosure: the publisher provided me with a free review copy of the book.

items.title:
üáßüá∑ Yesterday I visited the biggest indie hacker meetup of Brazil called Comunidade de Micro-SaaS

It...
items.content:
üáßüá∑ Yesterday I visited the biggest indie hacker meetup of Brazil called Comunidade de Micro-SaaS

It's organized by @brunomicrosaas who is a cool guy promoting this way of building a business (and has his own SaaS biz's too)

Very cool to see bootstrapping startups is becoming big in Brazil too

One thing you have to know is that Brazil is actually very modern in terms of startups, they have Revolut-like fintechs like NuBank, Amazon-like same day/hour delivery with MercadoLivre and their own DoorDash called iFood

Once startups are big in Brazil they usually quite easily expand to the rest of South America by just adding Spanish as a language (like iFood), South America is still too different for US startups and not always worth it to enter so they do

In many ways Brazil feels like South East Asia in terms of tech, startups and convenience, very modern

One cool person we met there is @thisabri who isn't a coder at all but built her own startup with Lovable and it blew up in Brazil and became very successful

@jrkelly @PearlF Hey Jason - worked with your team when I was at AWS, good to hear from you again. 
...
items.content:
@jrkelly @PearlF Hey Jason - worked with your team when I was at AWS, good to hear from you again. 

Questions:

1) OpenAI says the SOTA was beat in 3 iterations and 2 months. Paper says total was 6 iterations and 6 months. Why did the second half of experiments take twice as long?

2) press release says pydantic model is open sourced. Paper only links to general pydantic schema. Are you releasing all three models and validation criteria? 

Thanks again. Very cool use case.

items.summary: Allie K. Miller asking pointed technical questions about discrepancies in an OpenAI paper - specifically about why second half of experiments took twice as long and whether pydantic models/validation criteria will be open sourced

items.content_html:
@jrkelly @PearlF Hey Jason - worked with your team when I was at AWS, good to hear from you again.

Questions:

1) OpenAI says the SOTA was beat in 3 iterations and 2 months. Paper says total was 6 iterations and 6 months. Why did the second half of experiments take twice as long?

2) press release says pydantic model is open sourced. Paper only links to general pydantic schema. Are you releasing all three models and validation criteria?

Thanks again. Very cool use case.

items.title:
Where do you find ‚Äúcracked‚Äù computer science talent?

 An entrepreneur I know, who has a fast growin...
items.content:
Where do you find ‚Äúcracked‚Äù computer science talent?

 An entrepreneur I know, who has a fast growing AI startup, and an amazing tech is looking for AI engineers. He asked me where to find an amazing engineer?

He isn‚Äôt alone. My lists have tens of thousands but most of them are either working for big dollars at some big company or are running their own company.

Which means he is looking for someone who hasn‚Äôt been discovered yet. Or will need to convince someone to leave their job to join him.

In the past founders tell me they find people like that who are customers, or at hackathons.

I get this kind of request so often from entrepreneurs that I thought I would put it out there to see if a founder wanted to share their secret sauce?
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer asking where to find 'cracked' AI engineering talent for startups, noting scarcity as top talent is at big companies or running their own
items.reasoning: High engagement (102 likes, 11.5K views), substantive discussion of AI talent shortage and where founders find engineers. Practical insights about hackathons and customer conversion as talent sources
items.summary_html: Scobleizer asking where to find 'cracked' AI engineering talent for startups, noting scarcity as top talent is at big companies or running their own
items.content_html:
Where do you find ‚Äúcracked‚Äù computer science talent?

An entrepreneur I know, who has a fast growing AI startup, and an amazing tech is looking for AI engineers. He asked me where to find an amazing engineer?

He isn‚Äôt alone. My lists have tens of thousands but most of them are either working for big dollars at some big company or are running their own company.

Which means he is looking for someone who hasn‚Äôt been discovered yet. Or will need to convince someone to leave their job to join him.

In the past founders tell me they find people like that who are customers, or at hackathons.

I get this kind of request so often from entrepreneurs that I thought I would put it out there to see if a founder wanted to share their secret sauce?

items.title:
Most people underestimate what sign language actually is.

It‚Äôs not ‚Äúhands to words.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a visual...
items.content:
Most people underestimate what sign language actually is.

It‚Äôs not ‚Äúhands to words.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a visual language with:

‚Üí movement
‚Üí facial expression
‚Üí spatial context
‚Üí a kind of 3D grammar

If your AI model can‚Äôt understand space, it can‚Äôt understand sign.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Explains why sign language is fundamentally harder than text/speech for AI - requires understanding movement, facial expression, spatial context, and 3D grammar.
items.reasoning: Good technical explanation of multimodal AI challenges. Part of SignGemma thread. Educational value for understanding accessibility AI.
items.summary_html: Explains why sign language is fundamentally harder than text/speech for AI - requires understanding movement, facial expression, spatial context, and 3D grammar.
items.content_html:
Most people underestimate what sign language actually is.

It‚Äôs not ‚Äúhands to words.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a visual language with:

‚Üí movement

‚Üí facial expression

‚Üí spatial context

‚Üí a kind of 3D grammar

If your AI model can‚Äôt understand space, it can‚Äôt understand sign.

items.title:
task management approach

- quick tasks run while chatting
- complex tasks run as background objecti...
items.content:
task management approach

- quick tasks run while chatting
- complex tasks run as background objectives
- super long research tasks have their own lower priority type
- task queue uses prioritization based on urgency
- chat is async so you can ask for next thing while it's working
items.author: @yoheinakajima

I coined the term "prompt injection" and have been writing about it for years - but I don't think it's directly relevant to what Strong DM are doing here

They're using coding agents to build and test systems - prompt injection mainly affects tools that use LLMs to directly handle customer traffic

basic usage is similar to claw with multiple channels you can communicate with your agents, each with it's own context but also shared knowledge

it's very aware of it's owner and will always respond to you on all channels (i'm an imessage person, so went with @sendbluedotcom for blue bubbles and @agentmail)

items.title:
what's working? a lot of it!

- successfully created multiple reusable skills, including skills on t...
items.content:
what's working? a lot of it!

- successfully created multiple reusable skills, including skills on top of @attio skills that use @composio 
- kicking off long tasks via email and reporting back when done
- scheduling skills on a regular basis and running them
- using @browser_use to sign up for thing using it's own email
- saving and organizing it's own files

memory and context seem to work pretty well, though candidly i haven't pushed it hard yet
items.author: @yoheinakajima
items.summary: BabyAGI 3 capabilities working: reusable skills, Attio/Composio integrations, email-triggered long tasks, scheduled skills, browser_use for signups, file organization.
items.reasoning: Practical capability showcase of BabyAGI 3's working features.
items.summary_html: BabyAGI 3 capabilities working: reusable skills, Attio/Composio integrations, email-triggered long tasks, scheduled skills, browser_use for signups, file organization.
items.content_html:
what's working? a lot of it!

  • successfully created multiple reusable skills, including skills on top of @attio skills that use @composio
  • kicking off long tasks via email and reporting back when done
  • scheduling skills on a regular basis and running them
  • using @browser_use to sign up for thing using it's own email
  • saving and organizing it's own files

memory and context seem to work pretty well, though candidly i haven't pushed it hard yet

items.title:
Did you get mad at comments made earlier this week at that music show? 

I figure I‚Äôll just create m...
items.content:
Did you get mad at comments made earlier this week at that music show? 

I figure I‚Äôll just create my own, giving me a chance to test out new music video creation tools. This whole interaction took just minutes, including the time I took to write the lyrics over on @suno. I had it create me a song, then took it to https://t.co/ItjXqDriJE @vidmuse_ai and had that create me the music video you see here. 

The AI did everything but the lyrics, which I wrote.

More in thread -->>
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer demonstrating full AI music video workflow: lyrics via Suno, video via VidMuse, completed in minutes
items.reasoning: Good engagement (27 likes, 3.4K views), practical demonstration of end-to-end AI content creation pipeline combining multiple tools
items.summary_html: Scobleizer demonstrating full AI music video workflow: lyrics via Suno, video via VidMuse, completed in minutes
items.content_html:
Did you get mad at comments made earlier this week at that music show?

I figure I‚Äôll just create my own, giving me a chance to test out new music video creation tools. This whole interaction took just minutes, including the time I took to write the lyrics over on @suno. I had it create me a song, then took it to https://t.co/ItjXqDriJE @vidmuse_ai and had that create me the music video you see here.

The AI did everything but the lyrics, which I wrote.

More in thread -->>

items.title:
I upgraded Llambada to support multiplayer games.

Now anyone can create their own multiplayer games...
items.content:
I upgraded Llambada to support multiplayer games.

Now anyone can create their own multiplayer games to play with family and friends. No coding required: you simply explain to the AI what your game should be like and how many players it should support.

The first available game that I created myself is, of course, a Pong-like paddle ball game.

Check it out with a friend and let me know if you see any issues: https://t.co/mXQwwmhiDk
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov announces Llambada multiplayer game support - create games by talking to AI, no coding required
items.reasoning: Interesting demo of AI capabilities but primarily self-promotional.
items.summary_html: Burkov announces Llambada multiplayer game support - create games by talking to AI, no coding required
items.content_html:
I upgraded Llambada to support multiplayer games.

Now anyone can create their own multiplayer games to play with family and friends. No coding required: you simply explain to the AI what your game should be like and how many players it should support.

The first available game that I created myself is, of course, a Pong-like paddle ball game.

Check it out with a friend and let me know if you see any issues: https://t.co/mXQwwmhiDk

items.title: @jdelmerico @SenMarkey They are scaling up worldwide‚Äîit's not just in America. I disagree, and anywa...
items.content:
@jdelmerico @SenMarkey They are scaling up worldwide‚Äîit's not just in America. I disagree, and anyways, they're not there for safety. They're there to take over if the car gets in a pickle. 

My Tesla drives everywhere without humans, so the AI is there. It's the same thing with Waymo. This idea that a human is actually driving is not correct; the AI is driving 99.999% of the time. The human is only there if it gets into something that the AI can't figure out how to get out of.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer arguing that Tesla and Waymo AI is driving 99.999% of the time, humans are backup only
items.reasoning: Substantive take on autonomous vehicle AI capabilities, claims Tesla drives everywhere without human intervention
items.summary_html: Scobleizer arguing that Tesla and Waymo AI is driving 99.999% of the time, humans are backup only
items.content_html:
@jdelmerico @SenMarkey They are scaling up worldwide‚Äîit's not just in America. I disagree, and anyways, they're not there for safety. They're there to take over if the car gets in a pickle.

My Tesla drives everywhere without humans, so the AI is there. It's the same thing with Waymo. This idea that a human is actually driving is not correct; the AI is driving 99.999% of the time. The human is only there if it gets into something that the AI can't figure out how to get out of.

items.content: @thegautamkamath I think the best setup was the old CMT style rebuttal. A 1 page PDF, or ~1000 character limit. No back and forth. Authors should have the chance to make a straightforward clarification that saves the paper, without requiring a whole new review cycle. But there should be limits.

items.content_html: @thegautamkamath I think the best setup was the old CMT style rebuttal. A 1 page PDF, or ~1000 character limit. No back and forth. Authors should have the chance to make a straightforward clarification that saves the paper, without requiring a whole new review cycle. But there should be limits.

The opportunity isn‚Äôt novelty, it‚Äôs infrastructure.

Developers can use this to build tools that actually empower Deaf communities:

‚Üí classrooms
‚Üí customer service
‚Üí public services
‚Üí accessibility layers inside products

This is what multimodal AI is supposed to be for.

items.title:
That‚Äôs why ‚Äúsign-to-text‚Äù is a real milestone.

A new model trained on American Sign Language can tr...
items.content:
That‚Äôs why ‚Äúsign-to-text‚Äù is a real milestone.

A new model trained on American Sign Language can translate sign into English.

Even more important:

It‚Äôs designed to adapt to other sign languages.

That‚Äôs the difference between a demo and a platform.
